nodes.text: The Almost Ideal Demand System (AIDS) provides a flexible, theoretically consistent, and practically estimable demand system that is preferable to existing models for testing and extending conventional demand analysis
AIDS is derived from a PIGLOG class expenditure (cost) function log c(u,p) = (1-u) log a(p) + u log b(p) with specific flexible functional forms for log a(p) and log b(p)

AIDS budget share equations are linear in parameters: wi = ai + sum_j yij log pj + beta_i log(x/P), with P a price index, and the model can impose homogeneity, adding-up, and Slutsky symmetry as linear restrictions
AIDS permits exact aggregation over heterogeneous households under PIGLOG/PIGL assumptions, producing aggregate budget shares equivalent to a representative consumer with representative budget x/k

AIDS is a flexible functional form giving an arbitrary first-order approximation to any demand system (derived from utility maximization or not), and includes several known models as special or related cases

Derivation uses Shephard duality: price derivatives of the cost function yield quantities and logarithmic differentiation of log c(u,p) yields budget share equations as functions of prices and utility, then inverted to function of prices and expenditure

AIDS estimation strategy: approximate price index (Stone index) can linearize the model allowing OLS equation-by-equation, or estimate full nonlinear system by concentrated maximum likelihood with iterative substitution and imposed linear constraints

Application to UK annual data (1954-1974) on eight nondurable expenditure groups using both levels and first differences, estimating with Stone price index then iterating to full symmetric price index and testing homogeneity and symmetry by likelihood ratio and F-tests

Empirical result: Homogeneity of degree zero in prices and expenditure is decisively rejected for several equations in levels (notably food, clothing, housing, transport), and imposing homogeneity introduces positive serial correlation in residuals of the most rejected equations

Empirical result: Slutsky symmetry (cross-price symmetry) is rejected for the system as a whole by likelihood-ratio tests even after accounting for homogeneity; many yij coefficients are significantly different from zero and the model yields plausible expenditure and own-price elasticities

Evidence: In levels estimations using Stone index, many yij coefficients significant (22 of 64 with |t|>2), expenditure elasticities indicate food and housing as necessities, transport and communication price elastic, and homogeneity tests produce large F-ratios and reductions in fit

Limitations and diagnostic findings: symmetric homogeneous AIDS estimates sometimes violate concavity (positive eigenvalues of K matrix), fuel shows implausible positive compensated own-price elasticity, and omitted dynamics, price expectations, or distribution index k may explain homogeneity/symmetry rejections

Conclusion: Despite some empirical limitations and need to model omitted variables or dynamics, the AIDS's simplicity, flexibility, theoretical consistency, and aggregation properties make it a recommended platform for testing, extending, and improving demand analysis
